name: The Ricky Gervais Guide to: Comic Relief

transcript.content: St. Francis of Assisi once said: "Where there is charity and wisdom, there is neither fear nor ignorance." Acts of human charity have been documented since the beginning of recorded history. Yet even now, in the most democratic and economically advanced nations, charity is still necessary. Does this mean that charitable acts are failing to affect meaningful change? Should charity even be the responsibility of individual citizens, or is it the obligation of government? Do handouts make people lazy, independent, instead of resourceful and responsible for their own livelihoods? Is it every man for himself, or are we all in this together? To discuss these questions and more, I'm joined by Stephen Merchant, award winning writer and graduate of the University of Warwick.
Hello.
And Karl Pilkington.
Ricky pauses and sighs
Gonk.
Alright.
Intro music
So Red Nose day, Comic Relief has come round again.
Yeah. Red Nose Day is obviously the very specific date in the calendar for the whole generic term, comic relief, I think.

It's normally when the telecast happens, people know that that's the day when they can dress up, do charitable acts. But of course, Comic Relief is a charity that's working all the time for disenfranchised all over the world.
And you can go to the website all year round, which is ComicRelief dot com.
I think there's also RedNoseDay dot com, which is if you particularly want to donate for this year's appeal. Have you always been a strong champion of comic relief, Karl?
Not really.
Steve and Ricky laugh silently
Why was I expecting that answer?
But we're doing a bit of charity now. We're donating our time. It's not much, it's not costing anything.
But I do loads of stuff without going on about it. I don't think you should shout about how much you did for charity, because then who you're doing it for.

Oh, exactly. I mean, well, this is my thing, isn't it? That there's a lot of people that only do it if it's in the public eye. It's to do it really to be a busy body or to show off or to feel good about themselves. And I suppose that's good and bad. I mean, if it gets you involved, if it does some good.
My gift to the world has been you, Karl. To be quite honest. I feel that you're the world's now.
I'm sure there's people in Africa going 'We'd prefer blankets!"
Ricky laughs
Yeah
Doing a will is charity, isn't it?
Is it?
Sort of.
No, it is.
I mean, if you make a donation to a charity within the will, I suppose that's quite charitable. But just giving money to your relatives isn't, is it?
Of course it is. Well, they shouldn't have it.
They're getting somewhat for nothing, but... I don't know. It's giving something away that you have no use for.
Exactly!
Yeah, but forget that. It's "someone is getting something when they've done nothing for it" really.

Well, I suppose it is charity, but charity is usually infused with some sort of altruism. It's usually to do with them giving a piece of something that is kindly because you could do with it. Not strictly. I think you can give away something you don't need. But it's hardly donating a kidney, is it? Or some of your wages. It's like, it's not charity on your part because you're literally not around anymore. So it's no longer you giving it.
Yeah but I could either give it them or not give it them. Once I'm dead and have turned to mush, I shouldn't be worrying about Suzanne's mam getting a table.
Steve laughs
Is that what you're leaving her?
Well, I'd call up my dad first.
Why are you doing a will? For the show?
Because of this travel thing and it can get dangerous.
But why have you done a will up to now?
Because you sort of. I don't know, I felt sort of young and free.
Steve laughs
Whereas now....
I've never... That's not two words I've associated with Karl.
Ricky laughing
No...
He's always seemed like a man who's in his late 50's.
Yeah exactly. Yeah.
Certainly never the idea that you're free.
It's more...
Even if We just talk about the head alone, it's the head of a late 50 year old.
Free of hair!
Yeah, totally free of fucking hair.
I'm sort of getting on first name terms with me doctor.
Oh, really?
Chatting more. Oh, what is it this time?
How's your middle finger? Not too bad, Karl.
You know all that sort of thing. So it's just made me think.
Have you had that done for the will, by the way? For insurance and stuff?
I think you need to don't you, for a will.
I think you do.
There's nothing on the paper.
The prostate exam.
No.

Listen, for insurance purposes, I think you need to have a testicular exam for testicular cancer. You're just leaving the high risk for testicular cancer, actually. And you're entering the high risk for prostate cancer.
And you can have both at the same time.
The examination at the same time.
You could have both at the same time. If he's a very dexterous doctor.
I wouldn't want that.
Why? Too much like, too playful?
It's just too much going on. It's like someone juggling you.
Ricky and Steve laugh
Yeah, it's like being examined by Squiddly diddly.
And so you said you called up your dad.
Called him up. I said, is he anything you want if I die?
Right. And presumably you know, Suzanne she's getting the lion's share?

She is. But then the fella who was on the end of the phone talking us through it, was going, "oh you should get married." I was going, "oh shut up." He's saying, "Well, it makes things a lot easier when it comes to this." And it's like, well, that isn't a reason to get married, is it?
Well..
So she can have all my stuff. I said, I've wrote on the bit of paper that she can have it. I'm not bothered.
What have you wrote?
Whatever we've got, she can have.
Yeah, great, that's fine. That's as good as a marriage then isn't it.
Yeah, but it's something about tax, if you're not married, you have to hand over more.
Well, she'll get. Yeah, I suppose if it's money, she'll pay tax on it.

Yeah, I think you get so much and then it's like ridiculous tax rate. But she's going, that's why we should get married. I'm going to be paying tax. Going, hang on a minute, she's already like thinking about money loss. Instead of me disappearing, she's going, yeah, we should. I said, look, you'll be getting a load of money. I said, if I die on this program anyway, I'm insured. You'll be getting about a million pounds for that.
Yeah.
I said, so that's something you haven't got now.
Yeah.
Got nowhere near that now. I said, so even if you have to pay tax on that. I don't think it'd be right to get married. Just in case I get killed.
Well, you are married, aren't you?
It's as good as.
Well, then you get the paperwork.
No, because then everyone wants a party.
You don't need to have a party. You can go straight down the registry office.
Honestly, people start going, oh, you should do this. And, oh, it's not a proper wedding unless you do that.
Have you also two sets of parents met?
No.
That'd be good, would it?
Well

Well, I suppose it's a reason to in it, at least if you're getting married, there's a reason for them to meet. At the moment, there's no reason for them to meet. They'd get on each other's nerves. My dad wouldn't get on with a man.
Why?
Just wouldn't. She doesn't like me, so she won't like me dad because he's just an exaggerated version, I think it doesn't need.
To happen, but you could just knit down the registry office, get it done, dun or dusted, and you just phone up your folks and say, it's already happened.

I said, listen, if we had to do it, I said, if it was like, we've got to do it. For some reason, I said, I'd do that. We can have it done by two. You can be back in work for three. Because at the end of the day, we've known each other for years. We're not going to suddenly turn into some sort of Tom Hanks and Meg Ryan film just because we've got married. It's going to be the same. Exactly same. Except you'd want a joint bank account or something. That's the only other thing that would probably change. And I don't like the idea of that.
Why?
Just I like to know what's going on. There's enough people sticking their hand in my account, charity wise and all that, without an extra hand going in.
Who happens to be the love of your life.
I'm not moaning about it. I'm just saying it works the way it is. You hear about people getting married and it doesn't last. Adds extra pressure.
What pressure is it going to add? It's not going to add any pressure.
I suppose that you resent the fact that the only reason you would be getting married is because she gets your money after your death, tax free.
What if you gave her a series of challenges so that she sort of earned the right to have that?
It just keeps her on her toes. Because whilst we're not married, it's easy to go. I'm sick of this. So it keeps.
It keeps her on her toes.
It keeps us both sort of find. She's got to work hard to keep you, hasn't she?
You never do anything in order to sort of maintain this relationship, as far as I can tell. I'm not saying you're a bad guy, but in terms of romantic Meg Ryan type stuff, you never do anything.

Me and Jane were out with them and Suzanne the other night, right, at dinner. And honestly, he is so grumpy. He was saying about for Christmas, right? He said, you've had a floor. You've had a floor. Now, what did that mean?
We had a new floor put in.
But how is that her floor?
Because she wanted it.
But you walk on it, too.
I paid for it. I don't understand what you.
Don't you understand that like a romantic break or clothes or perfumes, sort of things that are kind of indulgent for a lady, that's a gift, not a new floor.
That is like some you give to some little African fella on comic relief. In fact, I think I saw it once. He didn't have a floor.
Exactly.

They built him the floor. I remember watching it with you? And they gave him a new pair of shoes and the floor, he went, hold on, floor or shoes? When that tsunami hit and it was like a month after Christmas, they showed that Britain had given 2 billion pounds. Right? He was going, that's enough. He said. Before they were living in mud huts, now there's an Arndale centre. So you think charity is all right? As long as people don't get above their station with charity, I think it.

Should be there as a little booster. Something's happened that they didn't expect. They're all a bit in shock. I don't think they'll feel bad because all they ever seem to do, these countries that are struggling, they never give anything back.
Right.
They've always got their hand out. And it's been like that since I was a kid. I remember being a kid, people knocking on the door, my mum going, don't look at the door, there's someone there.
Ricky and Steve laugh
And we'd just pretend they weren't there.
Charity starts at home. Not at your home.
No, because it's all the time. I mean, my mam didn't like answering the door anyway. Even if it was the pools man, she'd sort of say, don't move, and he might not see that we're here.
So you just froze where a man was at the door?
Well, you just. Because the front room was near the door, so people could see in.
Right.
So you just sort of stayed there and pretend that either you can't hear him.
Like some sort of predator, like, they can't see if you don't move.
Even if he was peering in through the window and he could see you in there not moving.
So he looked through and there was three people just frozen, right? Like statues. Just their eyes looking at him and he's confused.
Steve laughs
They're clearly dead. I'll move on.
Ricky laughs
There's obviously been a gas leak.
And did you stay sitting or stand up or did you sort of, like, throw yourself?
No we just sat where you were and you just stayed still.
But did he ever look in and see?
I don't know because you didn't turn around, did you?
Steve laughs
So you would pretend you couldn't hear the door?
It's the easiest, honestly. The amount of times people would come round, it seemed to be the 80s had a lot of it because it was all the Avon thing when it was perfume. Tubberware.
What?
Tubberware.
Tupperware?
Yeah, the plastic boxes.
Ricky and Steve laugh
Tubberware...
Tubberware!
It's dishes for fat people. Here we go. These are big because they are fat fuckers like you to eat out.
There was a pools man.
Right.
Just a lot of charity stuff. Just a lot. It seemed to be the time the 80s that they suddenly found out they can sort of scav money off people.
Yeah.
Oh there was a lot of scavving.
So that's why we used to ignore the door.
I just love this image of you. You're in the lounge, you're having a little boogie, it's Christmas. Someone's tapping on the glass. Freeze. They just go, well, we'll move on.
Yeah.
Nothing here for us.
Hammer time. Silence. Okay, right, let's do the scenario. I'm at the door.
Ricky knocks on the desk
I can see you're in there. Might as well come open the door. Karl? Karl, why are you staying so still? Are you trying to avoid me?
Steve laughs
It's working.
Karl, your eyes are moving. Can you come to the door, please?
I suppose in the end you've got to move.

Karl? No, I'm going to stay here. I'm just going to stay here until you have to move. Karl? This is the most pointless podcast we've ever done. Me shouting your name and you pretending not to be here. Okay, and I'll move on then. Right.
It works.
Yeah.
Works perfectly.
Okay. Brilliant.
Because once they've got you, that's the whole thing with charity. Once they've stopped you in the street, if you've stopped, that's it.
Keeps on going.
You're handing something over.
Yeah.
I mean, the amount of times I've been stopped. I mean, the good thing now is you've got an ipod. So you can just either pretend you're on the phone or listen to music.
Or just stay very still.
Steve laughs
Just freeze. When someone says, can I trouble? Totally frozen?
That would be amazing because they're normally in one spot, aren't they?
As soon as they stop you, you just freeze there.
So it's just they're carrying on selling and you've got to stay there for the rest of it outside Waitrose for 7 hours.
Ricky laughs

It goes dark. Well, I've finished my shift, I'm off. And then your eyes just see them walk away like that, and they all meet in their little tunics. And then you start walk, they look back and you freeze. And then they walk on. And then you can go home 7 hours late.
If you would like to donate to Comic relief, why not visit rednoseday.com?

Ever since I was young, I've always liked going in charity shops, particularly because you find sort of interesting old records in there. Never sort of gone in there to buy clothes and stuff, but books, whatever. And I was in a charity shop, patronised them for years and I noticed that through the window there was like a paparazzi guy and he was taking pictures of me through the window. I was a bit weird and obviously the old ladies in there and they didn't have any idea who I was, so they just thought that was a bit strange. And then it was in one of the magazines, like the kind of celebrity magazines. Oh, here's Steve Merchant. Despite all the money he must have made from his various projects, he's still going in charity shops. And you just think, but how is that a bad thing?
Yeah I know.
I'm giving my money to a charity. Isn't that a noble cause? I mean, obviously that's not the reason I'm doing it. I'm doing it...
To save 50p?
To save 50p of course!
But they don't know.
They don't know that.
No.
They don't know me!
You might be going there and going, keep the change, love. You never have said that.
Never said that.
Never said that in your life.
No.
Occasionally I'll shoplift! I'm no mug. 70p?! Don't you think that seems frustrating, though, that?
Yeah, but what do you expect? What are they going to do? They're not going to say, Steve Merchant, heart of gold are they?
I just thought all these things would slowly accumulate towards the OBE.
Yeah, I know. I think you got to do a bit more than get Roger Whittaker's greatest hits for 10p.

My mum's always in them and because my mum goes in them, my dad sort of got into going into them now because the weather's not good or whatever, and he thinks rather than standing outside. He went in one and he was after a jacket, just like, sort of a casual but quite smart. He's quite a big bloke, so it's difficult to find them, right? So he's in there, sees the jacket, goes, oh, look, here's that sort of jacket that I'm after. Picks it up, tries it on, fits. It's good, this in it. She's going, yeah, well, she's looking at a toad that you put money in or whatever. So he gets to the counter and it's got a price tag on it, eight quid, right? So he said, I'll give you six quid. He had six quid in his pocket.
Yeah.

Here you are, give you six quid for that? She went, no, it's eight pounds. Now that's wrong innit? That's a good price and it's six quid. They've got it for nothing and she wouldn't have any of it. He said, surely, surely something's better than nothing. If you don't give me this for six quid, it's going back on the hanger. And they said, no, sorry.
Yeah, but they might later sell it for eight pounds.
But they might not. And it's been given to them for free. What does it matter?
But the old lady's not...
Who's come up with the price of eight quid? Who is this?
Yeah.
They don't know how much it's worth.
She's not there to haggle. Someone's priced up and she's just a volunteer.
Maybe she thought of it, that she was losing the charity two pounds, as opposed to gaining it six.
But they haven't gained anything because he put it back on. And how many people want it? How many people are looking out for that jacket?
It might have been the principle. She might have thought, oh, you can't haggle when it's for charity.

It was a fair price. Someone. I give a lot of stuff to charity. A lot. Most of the time, just because it's nearer than the wheelie bin is. It's just a way of getting rid of garbage. Most of the time with me. Stick it all in a bin bag. Good stuff on the top. The stuff that you're embarrassed about, stick it in the bottom of the bag. Run in.
What are you embarrassed about?
Just old shoes, trainers.
Some of the books you've written.
Socks...
Socks?!
Underpants.
Underpants?! You do not give underpants to charity.
Washed.
But who's gonna...
Steve laughs
Ricky and Steve together
Washed.
Washed. I know. As opposed to just, like, peeling them off.
I don't know why you've got a problem with underpants, but shoes, you see I'd never buy shoes.
Who's buying underpants from a charity shop. I don't care how low you are on the socioeconomic level, you can get about 14 pairs for a quid in some places.
I know. I don't know who's buying underpants. I don't know who's buying your underpants. Definitely don't know.
I mean if they were signed...
That is something I like doing, though. When I've given to charity, I like going past the shop and seeing if it made it in the window.
Any success?
Yeah, recently, the one not far from here had me egg cups in the window. So it's like, oh, look.
What you've got a new set of egg cups. So you've got rid of your old ones.
Yeah.
I don't think we've got any egg cups.
Haven't you?
No. I don't think so.
Why not? You don't have boiled eggs.
I can't imagine. You'd be too impatient to boil an egg, Rick.
Well, yeah, it's just those things you think of never buying, like egg cups...
A whisk.
No, but you do eventually.
I suppose you've got to haven't you? Yeah. It's things that were just always there when you grow up, isn't it, that you have to go and you think, you know, think of. But not secondhand though.

But there's nothing wrong, honestly. I mean, it's made the window space, that's how good it was. It had hardly been used, that egg cup, because it was a doubler and I think they were quite small for the egg size that I get. I think they were made more for the small egg and I have the large egg.
Right.
So it was never really..
Just like your underpants.
Have you ever been a charity shopper, Rick?

Yeah. What I used to do a lot of was records and tapes and things like that but it ended up sort of being ironic. It really ended up like, you know, something like Shane Richie's greatest hits and things like that.

A bit of a dilemma that my auntie Nora had. She likes charity shops as well. She's got a neighbour, went out to Gracelands - big Elvis fan. They came back, she said, how was Gracelands? Said, oh, it was brilliant. Best holiday we've ever had. Probably go back again. We've got a gift for you. Right. They get out this clock, it's like a little Swiss. You know the Swiss sort of looks like a little house, like a cuckoo clock. But on the hour little Elvis comes out the top and goes "Uh huh uh".
Steve laughs
So she went, oh, cheers. She's not really into Elvis, she's more into Jim Reeves and Glenn Campbell and stuff. But what can you say? Oh, thanks for that. She put it in, took it in the house.

Maybe they could get attachments. Maybe you get a little Jim Reeves to pop on the spring, change it, anything you like, like, uh, So Solid Crew, you can get a little So Solid Crew, and that pops out or whoever!
So anyway, it's in the house. She's thinking, I'm not going to put that up. It's not her sort of thing. So uh, she thinks, give it to charity.
Of course.

She goes down to charity shop, gives them that, thinks nothing of it, goes off to the pub for an afternoon drink. Anyway, next day she's going out for afternoon drink again, passes the charity shop, it's in the window.
Oof. And the chances are her friends are going to pass by.
That was the dilemma.
Of course.
She had to buy it back.
Steve laughs
That's brilliant.
At a hugely inflated price.

For those that are American listeners, Comic Relief here is a, sort of... It happens every other year and you know people often do things in their workplace or at school. They can dress up, they can raise money in different fun ways. And we were told in a school assembly it was Comic Relief next Friday, everyone has to come along dressed up in fancy dress to school on that day.
Has to?!
Yeah, they said you have to dress up. They said, you pay 50p towards Comic Relief and you have to pay a pound if you don't dress up.
That's annoying innit.

So, of course I'm looking forward to this because you know, I'm a sort of aspiring comedian and that. Get to dress up like a clown. Right. Spent quite a lot of time getting the old clown outfit together.
What did that look like?
The shoes, obviously. I just wore my regular shoes.
Exactly,
Yeah.
But I had the red nose, a wig.
Wow.

You know, the whole deal. Big bow tie that my mum made for me. I thought, this is going be to the best day ever. Right, get to school. I want you to picture this scene right, during the assembly in my class of 30. School uniform. School uniform. School uniform. School uniform. School uniform. School uniform. Lanky kid dressed as a clown. School uniform. School uniform. School uniform. School- There was three people in the entire school who dressed up.
But Steve, you're 50p up!
Ricky and Steve laugh

Yes. But then worse than that, it turns out I was furious because I look like an utter dick. Obviously. Um, it turns out that what had happened- I don't know whether I'd missed this information, but apparently the headmaster must have had another assembly where he told people that he wasn't allowed to enforce that rule about making people pay.
Right, well, that's good.
Against their will. So obviously no one showed up dressed like an utter dick except me and about two other knobs.

What disappoints me is that for a man who was a self professed aspiring comedian, you chose the least funny thing in the world to dress as. Clowns are anti-comedy. They suck comedy out of the room. It's nu-
You're right. And this is from a man who wanted to dress as Hitler at the Golden Globes.
Ricky laughs
Now that's funny.
He knows funny costumes.
Ricky laughs
But you were saying about the guys who bother you in the street. Did I tell you that- when I pretended to be foreign to try and get out of that, did I tell you that story?
Amazing.

Because I used to- a technique I used to develop at university was whenever people bothered me in the street, I would pretend to be sort of generic, foreign. I can't really do a foreign accent, but I would just be like, like if someone asked for directions, I was always worried about giving them the wrong directions, so I would just. 'Sorry, I don't- I don't really, eh, how you say, it's just kind of vague foreign.
Brilliant.
And I've periodically used this method throughout my life. And not so long ago, a guy stopped me with one of those charity tunics and I sprang into my old trick. I was like, "Sorry, I don't erm...."
An elderly Russian woman.
Aha ha, I don't know what voice that is. I don't know what accent that's supposed to be
It went from vaguely French to sort of eastern European beggar.
Yeah. I don't know what it was. And the guy, well, let me explain to him. "Sorry, I'm not from...."
This world.
Yeah.
I am from planet Snark.
And the guy said, are you Stephen Merchant?
No. Sorry! Not when you were famous?!
Oh, yeah.
No, you didn't.
Yeah.
Because it hadn't occurred to me. It was like a lapse of concentration.
No! God almighty!
It was a lapse of concentration because.
And did your bow tie spin around and you squirted in the water and ran away? That's what I's have done.
Because you know, it's one of those things. You know, you don't always remember that you've been on the TV. It's not like I instantly remembered that.
Amazing.
So.

But he says, are you Steve Merchant? And then you're in this position where you've got to go, either you've got to admit what you did or you've got to carry on the lie. And I chose the second one. I was kind of like, "I don't know who that is. I don't know what you're..." And he was like, "Really? You look a lot like him." I was going "I've never heard... I don't..."
In fact, you are Steven Merchant.
Freeze.
Both laugh

I'm always getting stopped. There's so many charities now. I think that's the other problem, actually, that there's so many now. Years ago, a problem wouldn't have been a problem. Whereas today, it's. Someone's got this problem, someone's got OCD. And we're collecting for that.
Right.
It's not just starving people anymore, it's everything. One little fault. They're out there with a clipboard asking for your bank details.
A lot of new diseases cropped up.
Definitely.
Particularly for these sort of rich and famous diseases that really....
Weren't around.
...third world people do not suffer from.
So I was in WH Smith's probably buying a Valentine's card.
Oh okay.
So there you go, you see? So I do do a bit.
"Is this the cheapest one you've got, love?"
And I bought a big bar of, like, Galaxy.
Ooooh. Cheaper than a box of chocolates. But, yeah still nice.
For me, that. Because they had an offer on. Right.
All talk over each other
This is what I'm saying.
Woah, Happy Valentine's day.
She's getting a card isn't she?
This is what I'm saying.
Yeah.
I felt awkward, because she could see that. Oh, he must have some money.
What, a big bar of galaxy and a...
Because you could afford some chocolate?
Well, it was like an impulse buy thing.
Yeah.
Right.
So she's thinking, he's got money to burn.
Yeah.
So at first, I didn't know who she was.
There's a guy there buying a big bar of Galaxy and a small card. Follow him.
Ha, Yeah.
Ricky does Mission Impossible music

So she's there. I'm thinking, she just works in WH Smith's. "Morning, sir." "All right? How's it going?" "Oh, have you got a minute?" So I'm thinking, oh, is it WH Smiths saying, you know, how often do you buy the Galaxy? Because they always do sort of surveys and stuff. So she said, "oh, you like chocolate?" I went, "yeah." She said, "Here you are have a chocolate." Right, little chocolate.
Yeah.
I ate it. Then she goes, "Right, are you aware of the problems in the world?" So I'm thinking, "Oh, what's this?" You see, they've been clever there.
Yeah.
Yes.
I can't say "No!" and walk off. I've had a bit of chocolate.
Sure, right, just freeze.
We're closing up now. We're closing the shop.
So I said, oh, yeah, there's loads of problems. I'm sick of it.
So she says, no, not yours, sir. There are some people who are starving.

Yeah. And I explained to her, I said, listen, I said, I've got loads of these charities every month. I said, my bank account is literally, because I don't use my current bank account that much. So you look at it with a statement. It's like tools for Africa, right? Help the aged, deaf kids.
There's another one, deafkids.com.
There's loads. Is tools for Africa. When they send people like Karl over to help out.
Yes. That is comic relief. Tools for Africa is another name for comic relief, if you watch it.

So anyway, so they do all this. She's going, oh, that's very good of you, but we need your money as well. So she's saying, just as much as you can afford. Every little helps and everything. I've been here all day, as you can see. I haven't had much luck. It's not that busy in the shop, blah, blah. All right, then, right, so I give her the details, she looks at the amount, she goes, right? Now, the options are, we've got, you can tick the five pound box, the ten bounce box, the 20 pound box, the 50 pound box. This is a monthly payment, right? She said, will I put you down for a tenner?
